Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Advancing Sustainable Systems and Environmental Technologies to Serve Humanity (ASSETs to Serve Humanity)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The REU Site Program at Clarkson University is supported by the Division of Engineering Education and Centers, and has the theme of "Advancing Sustainable Systems and Environmental Technologies to Serve Humanity" (ASSETs to Serve Humanity). Program objectives include: (1) improve educational pathways to advanced science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) careers, (2) serve traditionally underrepresented students and students from colleges and universities lacking research opportunities in STEM fields, (3) develop a STEM workforce of actionable leaders on environmental sustainability, and (4) teach students to effectively communicate scientific research to shape future policy. Environmental leadership is promoted through engagement of ten or more undergraduate student participants in professional development activities and transformative research in sustainable and resilient energy and infrastructure; sensing, identifying, and mitigating emerging pollutants and other risks; and transformation of social policy and behaviors related to infrastructure, energy, and environment. Twenty faculty members of nine departments in the sciences, engineering, social sciences, humanities, and economics mentor participants on a self-contained portion of a larger research project. Students are instructed on hypothesis-driven research, data analysis, and effective dissemination of research results. Students participate in research group meetings, present their work at a University-wide undergraduate research symposium, write a final report, and are encouraged to publish their work with their mentor in peer-reviewed publications. Professional development includes graduate school preparation and workshops led by faculty mentors related to sustainable energy, sustainable infrastructure, and sensors for detecting and monitoring environmental hazards. Follow-on field trips to nearby locations that tie thematically to the workshops demonstrate real-world applications. Community-building activities foster cohesiveness among students. Formative and summative assessment assures program goals are accomplished.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The REU Site Program at Clarkson University is supported by the Division of Engineering Education and Centers, and has the theme of "Advancing Sustainable Systems and Environmental Technologies to Serve Humanity" (ASSETs to Serve Humanity). Achieving environmental sustainability and resilience to changing global conditions requires technological advancement produced by globally-competent engineers and scientists capable of adapting to the challenges of environmental, social, and cultural change. Twenty faculty members of nine departments in the sciences, engineering, social sciences, humanities, and economics provide integrated sustainability education, graduate training, and hands-on interdisciplinary research opportunities that spark the imaginations of young minds towards production of a STEM workforce of future engineers and actionable leaders on environmental sustainability. The ASSETs to Serve Humanity REU Site program has a proven record of full participation of women, persons with disabilities, underrepresented minorities, and high-achieving faculty mentors that understand the benefits of a diverse REU cohort. Recruitment and engagement is designed to assure continued excellence. Similarly, ASSETs to Serve Humanity REU participants have a proven record of scientific advancement reflected in peer-reviewed publications, presentations at state, national, and international conferences, research awards, and patent applications from their research at Clarkson University. Through this high degree of research dissemination, participants in the REU Site program at Clarkson University drive technological innovation needed to maintain public well-being in a more crowded and resource-limited world, and to improve the economic competitiveness of the United States. Several research projects are driven by academic-industry partnerships with goals of technological development and creation of economic opportunities and new jobs in technological fields. The information gained is transferrable towards new operations broadening the impact of these activities to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The multidisciplinary REU Site program in environmental sciences and engineering at Clarkson University has operated for more than 18 years, engaging nearly 200 talented and motivated students from colleges and universities across the United States and Puerto Rico in high-impact research projects that address emerging issues of energy supply and environmental quality. The most recent program title for 2014 through 2016 has been “Advancing Sustainable Systems and Environmental Technologies to Serve Humanity” (ASSETs to Serve Humanity). The program has included a broad array of projects led by accomplished and dedicated mentors within the theme areas of sustainable and resilient energy and infrastructure; sensing, identifying, and mitigating emerging pollutants and other risks; and transformation of social policy related to infrastructure, energy, and environment. The objectives of this REU Site program included:

(1) Improve pathways to advanced science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) education by preparing students and motivating them to continue on to graduate school.

(2) Provide students of diverse backgrounds opportunities to conduct research in interdisciplinary engineering and science in a supportive and challenging atmosphere.

(3) Develop a STEM workforce of actionable leaders on environmental sustainability by providing opportunities to practice the skills necessary to address future challenges through training and experience in hypothesis-driven and applied research.

(4) Teach students to effectively communicate scientific research that shapes future policy by providing training in oral, written, and interpersonal communication and ample opportunities to practice these skills.

Intellectual Merit: Forty research projects were completed by REU participants between 2014-2016. Research outcomes were translated to solutions for global environmental sustainability challenges such as effective social messaging to promote energy conservation, among others. REU participants co-authored eight publications in scientific journals and delivered 23 presentations at state, national, and international conferences. They published two research reports to state agencies, contributed to a book chapter, and developed new models for predicting behavior of pollutants in the environment and growth of seaweeds in integrated aquaculture systems. Several of the projects of this REU Site Program were driven by academic-industry partnerships with goals of technological development and creation of economic opportunities and new jobs in technological fields. New technologies co-developed by REU participants included low-cost sensor elements for automated detection of pollutants in aquatic systems and plasma-based treatment technologies to remove toxic chemicals from water among others. Through these high quality research outcomes, REU participants have driven further technological innovation. These advancements are needed to maintain public well-being in a crowded and resource-limited world, and to improve the economic competitiveness of the United States.

Broader Impacts: Achieving environmental sustainability and resilience to changing global conditions requires technological advancement produced by globally-competent engineers and scientists capable of adapting to the challenges of environmental, social, and cultural change. Meeting challenges of social and cultural change requires participation of a diverse workforce capable of understanding a multitude of viewpoints. This REU Site program has a record of participation of women, persons with disabilities, students underrepresented in science and engineering fields, and high-achieving faculty mentors that understand the benefits of a diverse workforce. Forty percent of our participants were from racial or ethnic groups underrepresented in science and engineering. Seventy percent of participants were women. Fifty percent were students from institutions with limited research opportunities. Two students participated in multinational research in Norway and the United States. To maintain a competitive edge in global technological development, United States industries are in dire need of engineers and scientists to grow their workforce. Integrated sustainability education, graduate training, and hands-on interdisciplinary research opportunities of this REU Site program have promoted a workforce of future engineers and actionable leaders on environmental sustainability. More than 60% of graduates of this REU Site program from 2014 to 2016 have entered advanced graduate study. The remaining graduates have entered technical careers in science and engineering. Long-term program data demonstrate that nearly 75% of graduates of this program will complete advanced graduate degrees within 10 years of graduation from their undergraduate degree programs, improving capacity of the technical workforce of the United States.
